title: 103_hr4484
content: The "FHA Improvement Act of 1994" aims to simplify and streamline the loan criteria and approval process for the single family housing mortgage insurance program. Congress believes that this will promote first-time and affordable homeownership without increasing risk to the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund. SEC. 3. LOAN FLOOR. The loan floor under the National Housing Act is amended to ensure a minimum dollar amount limitation for any area, based on specific criteria outlined in the amendment. The Secretary will establish a single amount for residences based on purchase prices, adjusted annually using the Constant Quality Housing Price Index. SEC. 4. CALCULATION OF DOWNPAYMENT. Section 203(b)(2) of the National Housing Act is amended to specify the maximum loan-to-value ratios for mortgages based on property appraised values. The amendment also includes details on mortgage insurance premiums. Amendment to Section 203(b)(2) of the National Housing Act removes certain sentences related to loan-to-value ratios and mortgage insurance premiums. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF INSURANCE BY MORTGAGEES. Section 215 of the National Housing Act is amended to allow mortgagees to endorse and issue insurance certificates for mortgages without the need for specific approval by the Secretary within a 180-day period. SEC. 6. ELIMINATION OF RESTRICTIONS REGARDING NEW CONSTRUCTION. Amends Section 203(b)(2) of the National Housing Act to remove restrictions on new construction. Repeals Section 518 of the National Housing Act. SEC. 7. AUTHORITY TO USE AMOUNTS BORROWED FROM FAMILY MEMBERS FOR DOWNPAYMENTS. The amendment allows borrowed amounts from family members to be considered as cash for mortgage purposes, with certain conditions regarding lien priority and total obligations not exceeding property value. The Housing Act is amended to define "family member" as a child, parent, or grandparent of the mortgagor. The term "child" is also defined to include stepchildren and stepdaughters of the mortgagor. SEC. 8. Approval of condominium projects. Section 234 of the National Housing Act is amended to allow mortgage insurance for multifamily projects approved by a government-sponsored housing enterprise, with specific requirements for eligibility. The amendment to Section 234 of the National Housing Act allows for mortgage insurance on multifamily projects approved by a government-sponsored housing enterprise, with specific eligibility requirements for mortgages, including blanket mortgages. The term 'condominium unit' refers to a 1-family dwelling unit in a multifamily property with an undivided interest in common areas. The term 'government-sponsored housing enterprise' includes the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. SEC. 9. INSURANCE OF 2-STEP SINGLE FAMILY MORTGAGES. Amendment to Title II of the National Housing Act to include a new section on 2-step single family mortgages. The Secretary has the authority to insure mortgages for properties with dwellings for 1 to 4 families, with fixed or adjustable interest rates for specified periods. The effective rate of interest on insured mortgages can be adjusted periodically by the mortgagee based on factors like monthly payment amount, outstanding principal balance, or mortgage term. The adjustment is tied to a specified national interest rate index approved by the Secretary. Extensions of the mortgage term cannot exceed 40 years. The interest rate adjustments for insured mortgages are periodically made based on factors like monthly payment amount, outstanding balance, or mortgage term. The adjustments are tied to a specified national interest rate index approved by the Secretary and are limited to a maximum increase of 1 percent annually on the outstanding loan balance. The Secretary may insure mortgages with interest rate adjustments limited to a 1 percent increase annually on the outstanding balance and a maximum increase of 5 percentage points above the initial rate over the mortgage term. Regulations require mortgagees to provide written explanations of 2-step mortgage features to borrowers at the loan application stage. The total number of insured mortgages is also limited. The Secretary may insure mortgages with limited interest rate adjustments. The total number of insured mortgages is capped at 10 percent of the previous year's total. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a study on reducing upfront and annual premiums for mortgage insurance under the single-family home mortgage insurance program. The study will also assess the impact of these methods on the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund's financial stability. A report with findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
